pullRequest.body:
Define a product of uniformities (`UniformityProd`) and prove a couple of lemmas (`ball_prod`, and the dubiously-named `UniformityProd_of_uniform_prod`). The goal is to make the manipulation of uniformities in product spaces more user-friendly.

The statement of another lemmas is reworded to use UniformityProd. I also reformulated a few lemmas to make them easier to grasp in the documentation.

[Zulip thread](https://leanprover.zulipchat.com/#narrow/stream/287929-mathlib4/topic/Product.20of.20entourages/near/449906080)

Edit: Paging Patrick, since you contributed to this file.

---

Should it be called `entourageProd`? Uniformity is the filter, not its base sets. @PatrickMassot

:v: D-Thomine can now approve this pull request. To approve and merge a pull request, simply reply with `bors r+`. More detailed instructions are available [here](https://bors.tech/documentation/getting-started/#reviewing-pull-requests).
bors r+

Pull request successfully merged into master.

Build succeeded:
  * [Build](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/10551291315/job/29228514246)
  * [Lint style](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/10551291315/job/29228514126)
bors d+
bors d+

I think this new spelling is worse; while the source may be more readable the generated `Expr` is much more verbose, as it now contains `match` statements (aka `uniformity_prod._match_1` and `uniformity_prod._match_2`)

I've reverted to the former spelling. The only one for which I've kept the new spelling is the (new) definition `UniformityProd`, which, if I'm not mistaken, doesn't generate anything strange.

That's a good lesson to always check the generated expressions; I'll keep that in mind!
Could consider `Equiv.prodProdProdComm _ _ _ _ ⁻¹' (u ×ˢ v)`, though maybe it's not better.

I've tried it, but in the end, I didn't see how it helped, and it made the definition slightly harder to parse for a human. The main issue being that there is almost no lemmas relating to `Equiv.prodProdProdComm`, and the little there is is easily `simp`-able, so I couldn't leverage this expression to make it useful.
Fixed the capitalization.
Done.

```suggestion
theorem mem_entourageProd {u : Set (α × α)} {v : Set (β × β)} {p : (α × β) × α × β} :
```
Could you also review the other theorem names?
Done.

```suggestion
/-- An entourage of the diagonal in `α` and an entourage in `β` yield an entourage in `α × β` once we
```
Done, thanks!

```suggestion
theorem ball_entourageProd (u : Set (α × α)) (v : Set (β × β)) (x : α × β) :
```

```suggestion
    p ∈ entourageProd u v ↔ (p.1.1, p.2.1) ∈ u ∧ (p.1.2, p.2.2) ∈ v := Iff.rfl
```
Should this (or a version for `((a₁, b₁), (a₂, b₂))`) be a `simp` lemma?

Done for the proof of `mem_entourageProd`.

I would vote against labelling it as a `simp` lemma. It would break up `entourageProd` a bit too easily and make it harder to use it in a deliberate fashion.

Please add a `Filter.HasBasis` combinator (not tested):
```lean
theorem Filter.HasBasis.uniformity_prod {ιa ιb : Type*} [UniformSpace α] [UniformSpace β]
    {pa : ιa → Prop} {pb : ιb → Prop} {sa : ιa → Set (α × α)} {sb : ιb → Set (β × β)}
    (ha : (𝓤 α).HasBasis pa sa) (hb : (𝓤 β).HasBasis pb sb) :
    (𝓤 (α × β)).HasBasis (fun i : ιa × ιb ↦ pa i.1 ∧ pb i.2) (fun i ↦ entourageProd (sa i.1) (sb i.2)) :=
    (ha.comap _).inf (hb.comap _)
```
Then `(𝓤 α).basis_sets.uniformity_prod (𝓤 β).basis_sets` will give you this lemma.
That works beautifully, thanks for the suggestion!

```suggestion
  (ha.comap _).inf (hb.comap _)
```

pullRequest.title: [Merged by Bors] - feat(UniformSpace.Basic): define product of uniformities
